instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hello.

I have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board that a few shops played around with. They were heating different controllers hoping it will power on. The main issue was a hole in the board on <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> Pin 5 side. I dug up and solved that, no more short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Also, I noticed that ''maybe'' on purpose they moved the Bios chip and no.1 to 4 pin were not in place and not making a contact. Also, they removed <CAPACITOR>C4202</CAPACITOR> and when just shorted it with solder  <SIGNAL>O_O</SIGNAL>  I got to a point where I'm getting 20V on the meter and all LDO lines on CD have proper voltages.

 Any suggestions would be appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
This may be waste of time...

What is actual <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I'm suspecting <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> since they also heated it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0v"
Diode mode to ground?

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> diode is 0.400, I didn't find any shorted line. In the meantime, I replaced <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> still the same.

<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> - 20v
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> - 5v
VDDA - 5v
VDDP - 5v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> 3.4v
AMON - 0v
BMON - 0v

Also, I've soldered back a new <CAPACITOR>C4202</CAPACITOR> because it was missing and it was the spot that they soldered together both contacts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_4FINGERS_RST</SIGNAL> too.

Also check R/C/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 and their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
On <CHIP>U5256</CHIP> i have all voltages besides  <SIGNAL>SMC_4FINGERS_RST</SIGNAL>  which is 0v. 
R/C/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 all look perfect no liquid damage or anything. I have <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> but no output on L7030 which you know by now :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I will like to have an "eye multimeter", as you.
However, I have my doubts about such "measurments".

Check <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:

I hope you can find a way to check them properly, apart of the "eyes"...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: All diode measurements are good on  R/C/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40. I never said that I measured anything with my eyes, of course, that I checked the diode values. If you have some advice for me I would appreciate it, if not thanks for your time and comedy  âœŒ ðŸ¥³

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: If you want i post the diode values i can do that no problem :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
You must check components correctly, between their pins, not diode mode to ground.

If all good around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, then you have a problem with SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Okey understood i will check all traces. I have a spare board for parts if needed to change the SMC. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> also i replaced new

threads.message: I have replaced another SMC still the same
